newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 16.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 16.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- President Fidel Ramos returns on Friday after a 10-day trip from the United States, Mexico, and Panama. (BULLETIN)
- A mayor in the southern Maguindanao province urged town mayors to organise their owned armed group to go after kidnappers. (INQUIRER)

- President Ramos defended Congress from the influential Makati Business Club's criticism that legislators were engaged more in politics than in their principal job of lawmaking. Ramos said the Congress had passed a total of 144 laws since he took office in 1992. (PHILIPPINE STAR)

- A priest named by a 1995 Central Bank report as one of 14 persons who approved a loan programme that caused the near collapse of the Monte de Piedad and Savings Bank denies any wrongdoing. (MANILA TIMES)

- The Central Bank on Thursday raised its overnight borrowing rate twice during the day to send a stronger signal againt currency speculators. The Bank raised the overnight borrowing rate by a total of 1.75 percentage points to 13 percent. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)

- Lingering fears that Thailand's economic malaise is affecting its neighbors sent Asian financial markets in a tailspin on Thursday. The Philippine composite index plunged almost three percent to 2,631.09 points. (BUSINESSWORLD/MANILA BULLETIN)

- The Securities and Exchange Commission has created a task force to investigate the recent market slump believed to have been triggered by rumour mongers and market manipulators. (PHILIPPINE STAR/TODAY)
- The Times Journal said the government posted a surplus of 18.2 billion pesos from January to end-April this year compared with 11 billion the same period last year.
